quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Shakespeare and Novel
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, actor, globe. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: From what Shakespeare play did Aldous Huxley derive the title of his famous novel, Brave New World?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Tempest

questions.question: Which Shakespeare comedy contains the following lesser known characters:  Quince, Snug, Snout, Flute, Bottom, and Starveling?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A Midsummer Nights Dream

questions.question: Which of these is the most accurate description of plot line of Thorne Smiths novel Passionate Witch?

options.text: A witch is reborn as a man who seeks revenge on those who killed him.
A 17th Century witch is transported into the 20th Century.
A curse by a witch follows a elderly couple through life.
A living statue of Aphrodite complicates the life of a mild-mannered accountant.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A 17th Century witch is transported into the 20th Century.

questions.question: For what role did Laurence Olivier win a Best Actor Oscar in 1948?
What character from the play Hamlet made famous the line, Something is rotten in the state of Denmark!?
The main character of which novel by Thorne Smith is turned into a skeleton?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Skin and Bones

questions.question: In which novel by Thorne Smith do all the main characters end up in court before a totally befuddled judge?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: all of these

questions.question: Shakespeare died on April 23, 1616. What other famous author died on the same day?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra

questions.question: First published in 1915, this poem by T. S. Eliot portrays upper class society as quite empty and lonely. Its epigraph is from Marlowes The Jew of Malta-

options.text: The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Portrait of a Lady

questions.question: William Shakespeare had two daughters and one son, named Susanna, Judith, and Hamlet.
In Night life of the Gods by Thorne Smith what object is responsible for the transformations that occur throughout the story?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A ring

questions.question: The famous Wedding March is incorporated in the music that German composer Felix Mendelssohn wrote in 1842 for what Shakespeare play?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A Midsummer Nights Dream

questions.question: In the novel The Bishops Jaegers by Thorne Smith, what are the jaegers?
The popular Globe Theatre was owned by actors in what famous playing company of the Elizabethan age?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Lord Chamberlains Men

questions.question: The drama, My Own Private Idaho, starring Keanu Reeves and the late River Phoenix, is adapted from this Shakespeare play.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Henry IV

quizzes.title: History Quiz: William Shakespeare and Character
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, buddhist, midwinter. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Name the play by William Shakespeare in which the character Sir Andrew Aguecheek appears.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Twelfth Night

questions.question: Angelo is a character from this famous play by William Shakespeare.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Measure for Measure

questions.question: Is this the correct usage of the word inferring?

options.text: saying that I look good today, are you inferring that I did not look good yesterday?

questions.question: Which vegetables are considered taboo food in Buddhist tradition?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Garlic and onion

questions.question: What American Modernist poet wrote the poem The Snow Man, which opens with the lines,
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Wallace Stevens

questions.question: In the following sentence, which word is incorrect?

options.text: None of the words is incorrect; the sentence is correct as is.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: None of the words is incorrect; the sentence is correct as is.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a synonym of the word reticent?

options.text: These are all synonyms of the word reticent.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: These are all synonyms of the word reticent.

questions.question: Is this the correct usage of the word continually?
What English poet wrote the poem In the Bleak Midwinter in which Snow had fallen, snow on snow,
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Christina Rossetti

questions.question: Shylock is a character depicted in this Shakespearean play.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Merchant of Venice

questions.question: Which of the following is incorrect?

options.text: These are all correct usages of the word comprised.
The class was comprised of 30 people.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: These are all correct usages of the word comprised.

questions.question: Which of these is correct?

options.text: The capitol building is located in the capitol.
The capital building is located in the capital.
The capitol building is located in the capital.
The capital building is located in the capitol.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The capitol building is located in the capital.

questions.question: In which play by William Shakespeare is the character King Claudius introduced?
Which of these sentences is correct?

options.text: From hence to eternity, I will search.
If you build it, thence he will come.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Whence did he come?

questions.question: Iago is the antagonist of which play by William Shakespeare?

quizzes.title: Knowledge Quiz: Sentences and Language
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Knowledge, danish, mean. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Which of the following sentences means I love you in German?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ich liebe Dich.

questions.question: Which expression would you use to say I love you in Danish?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jeg elsker dig.

questions.question: The monitoring, recording, and measuring of a living organisms basic physiological functions is known as this.
Which of these sentences means I love you in Spanish?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Te amo.

questions.question: Which of these is incorrect?

options.text: All of these sentences are correct.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: All of these sentences are correct.

questions.question: Enterokinase is this.
Name this artificially-constructed international language, in which Mi amas vin means I love you.
Volim te means I love you in three of these European languages. Which is the odd one?
Rakastan sinua is one of the ways to say I love you in which European language?
What is the Swahili expression for I love you?
In which Turkic language does Seni seviyorum mean I love you?
When something contains or yields an acid, it is this.
Which of these sentences means I love you in Dutch?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ik hou van jou.

questions.question: The implement, used to extinguish the flame of a candle, is called this.
In what European language does Je taime mean I love you?

quizzes.title: Science Quiz: Vampire and Vampires
quizzes.description: Test your science knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Science, parts, gerontology. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: The word vampire is a very controversial one, when it comes to its etymology. There are many theories about its origin and meaning. According to one of these theories, vampire comes from the Magyar words vam, meaning blood, and pir. What does pir mean in Magyar?

One of the most famous vampires is Dracula (some believe that he was the first vampire). In Romanian Dracul means either Dragon or Devil and therefore Dracula is translated as Son of the Dragon or Son of the Devil. Due to his favorite sadistic punishment, Vlad Dracula was nicknamed Tepes.  He preferred to kill those who opposed him in this manner.
Silver doesnt harm vampires.

One of the most popular ways of killing a vampire (apart from the trivial sharp wooden stick in the heart), is to expose the creature to sunlight. However, there is a disease, that has similar symptoms. People who suffer from it are very sensitive to sunlight and avoid going out during the day. What is this horrible disease?
Vlad Tepes was one of the major allies of the Ottoman Empire, therefore Romania was never put under Ottoman rule.

Peter Kurten was called a vampire, because he consumed the blood of some of his victims. He was accused of nine murders and seven attempted murders and was sentenced to death. He was guillotined on 2 June 1932. What was his nationality?
It is believed that you can stop a vampire, by throwing rice or marbles on the floor.
Hyperplasia is the abnormal increase in the number of these.
The authority to teach religious doctrine is referred to as this.
Gerontology is the branch of medical science that deals with diseases and problems specific to these people.

Of course everybody knows about the Blood Vampires. They feed on the blood of their victims and prefer sucking it from the neck, the wrist or the groin. But there is another, less known, kind of vampires.  What do they feed on?

This woman was believed to be a vampire. She was obsessed with her beauty and youth, and slaughtered as many as six hundred innocent women in an attempt to maintain her vitality. Although her guilt has never been proven, she is still one of the most famous serial killers in Hungarian and Slovak history.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Elizabeth Bathory

questions.question: Vampires are common to the folklore of many countries. The Civatateo is an Aztec vampire, created when a noblewoman died at childbirth. In aboriginal mythology, vampires had suckers on their fingers. What are the Yakshis (sort of Indian vampires) like?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Beautiful women

questions.question: Copious perspiration is known as this.
One of these terms means preserving the mutual relations of parts, especially as to size and form; maintaining relative proportion.

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Words and Mythology
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, marduk, deity. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: If I am famous for my steadiness of mind under stress, then I am famous for this.
Helicon is the name of an ancient lake, where the Muses were born.
The creature from Slavic mythology known as Zmey actually resembles a dragon.
Do the words equivoke and equivoque mean the same?
The great circle on the celestial sphere, midway between the celestial poles is called this.
Loki is the god of mischief of Norse mythology.
One of these words has mid-17th century Latin origins and is a synonym of the word, wavy.
Nike was a goddess, who personified triumph and victory (Greek mythology). Ironically, she was paralyzed and could not move her legs.
If a statement is ambiguous, it is said to be this.
One of the four pairs of words below contains two synonyms.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Equal - Equivalent

questions.question: Svarog is the highest god of the pantheon (Slavic mythology) and the god of thunder and lightning.
Calliope was the muse for music.
Marduk was a Mesopotamian deity.
Gilgamesh is a character from the Sumerian mythology.
Athena was the Greek equivalent of the goddess Minerva.

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Mythology and Word
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, judge, eskimos. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: The word “promiscuous? is used in physical description to refer to someone with exclusive charm and sex appeal.
Which of these words is used to describe something with a yellow color or tending toward a yellow color?
A cuero is a mythical giant octopus of which continent?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: South America

questions.question: Anubis was the jackal-headed judge of the dead from what mythology?
A dwarf is a little humanoid creature with a large head and a long beard, typical for what mythology?
The banshee, a female spirit in Irish mythology, is known for doing what?
Which of these definitions does not describe a present day meaning of the word sesquipedalian?

options.text: Characterized by the use of long words

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Having a lot of feet

questions.question: We all know purple and its numerous variations, but can you name the odd one in this synonymic order dedicated to the shade of purple?
The amarok, which is typical for the mythology of the Eskimos, is what kind of an animal?
The Kraken from seafaring lore was a monster often described as what?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Giant squid

questions.question: Having in mind the words meaning, does it  fit in the following analogy: Juvenile is to young as *geriatric* is to aged.
A brownie is a legendary elf popular in the folklore of which two countries?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: England  Scotland

questions.question: The archaic word wittol, already out of use and found mostly in old books, stands for a person who is very wise.
A ghul is an evil spirit encountered by travelers in what area of the world?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Arabian Dessert

questions.question: The hippocampus, a mythical monster with the head of a horse and body of a fish, pulled the chariot of which god?
